author: Matt Bamford
title: Record year for Aussie movies
text:
Video Image Oddball - Trailer 2:01 The true story about an eccentric chicken farmer who, with the help of his granddaughter, trains his mischievous dog Oddball to protect a wild penguin sanctuary from fox attacks and in the process tries to reunite his family and save their seaside town.
January 1st 1970 46 years ago /video/video.news.com.au/Entertainment/ Man’s best friend: Actor Shane Jacobson with Kai the golden retriever, both stars of winning Aussie flick Oddball. Picture: John Appleyard
Matt Bamford News Corp Australia Network BUMPER crowds and a bevy of critically acclaimed releases have made for a record breaking year for Australian cinema.
Last weekend 2015 became the biggest year for Australian film with over $64 million recorded at the box office for locally made movies.
Box office ticked past the previous record of $63.4 million from 2001.
ANIMALS ARE THE KEY TO AUSSIE FILM SUCCESS
LOCAL FLICKS SET FOR 10 PER CENT SHARE OF LOCAL BOX OFFICE
That year saw a host of classic Aussie films debut including the Nicole Kidman cabaret hit Moulin Rouge , the chilling family thriller Lantana and Paul Hogan’s Crocodile Dundee in Los Angeles.
Ed Oxenbould as Dylan in Paper Planes, a heartwarming family flick which has helped local box office to its best year since 2001. Source: Supplied
Still in the top spot after nearly 30 years is Hogan’s first appearance as the iconic wrangler in Crocodile Dundee which brought in over $47 million in 1986.
This year, blockbusters like the star-studded Mad Max: Fury Road ($21.6m) (shot in Namibia but directed and funded by Australians) and Russell Crowe’s The Water Diviner ($10m) are leading the pack bolstered by a groundswell of small budget gems like Paper Planes ($9.6m) and Last Cab to Darwin ($7m).
Actor and director Shane Jacobson, whose feel-good film Oddball ($8m) has been an instant hit since it premiered last month, and is still screening, said the all-round performance proves the public will support quality cinema.
“This restores faith in film goers and film makers,” he said.
“A lot of the Aussie films this year have a great heart and a great story.”
“I’m thrilled, it’s really exciting for the industry.”
“For Oddball, god, you hope it goes well but this level of success is a dream come true,” Jacobson said.
Man’s best friend: Actor Shane Jacobson with Kai the golden retriever, both stars of winning Aussie flick Oddball. Picture: John Appleyard Source: News Corp Australia
Screen Australia head of business and audience development Richard Harris said after a few lean years, the results were encouraging.
“It’s amazing, especially because this is the most challenging time for cinema in Australia,” he said.
“With the advent of streaming services audiences are much more discerning.”
With fast-paced action spectacles standing alongside children’s comedies and challenging dramas, Mr Harris said the range of films succeeding at the box office was reassuring.
“What’s really exciting is the diversity of the films. There’s a whole suite of films from a range of genres.”
With a number of highly anticipated films yet to debut including Brett Lee’s UnINDIAN and The Dressmaker, industry experts are quietly confident 2015 box office totals could surpass $70 million.
2015: the year so far
Mad Max Fury Rd : $21.65 million
The Water Diviner : $10.18 million
Paper Planes : $9.65 million
Oddball : $8.12 million
Last Cab to Darwin : $7.15 million
Blinky Bill The Movie : $2.32 million
That Sugar Film : $1.71 million
Holding the Man : $1.14 million
Ruben Guthrie : $0.42 million
Manny Lewis : $0.41 million
